entry.title: Re: Display PDF document as RAP Odata V4 Web API output
entry.content:
Hello Juwin,

Thank you for the response. However, I couldn't use it. Since, there is a custom existing solution to get the archived file from multiple document types developed in V2 service, organization wishes to reuse it for the ODdata V4 WebAPI development. And the OData V4 solution works fine now. Issue was with the URI. As like V2 service, we can't provide $value at the end of V4 uri. We need to just mention the property name at the end of URI.

https://<your-sap-host>/sap/opu/odata4/<service-namespace>/<service-name>/<version>/<entity-set>(<key>)/<name of the property with document data>

Thank you for the support!

Happy Learning!

Kind regards,

Shahanaz.

entry.title: Re: Equipment transfer from one plant to another plant
entry.content:
You can achieve this requirement in SAP ECC using standard asset transfer and equipment reinstallation processes, combined with proper master data updates and history tracking via equipment and asset reports.

Go to transaction ABUMN (Transfer Within Company Code) to move the asset from one plant to another. Ensure both plants belong to the same company code. Update the cost center, location, and plant fields during the transfer. This will move the asset value and update the asset master record. If the plants are in different company codes, use ABT1N (Intercompany Asset Transfer) instead.

Change the location, plant, and cost center in the equipment master. Link the equipment to the new asset number if needed. This ensures the equipment is correctly tied to the new plant and asset.

If the equipment is also managed as a material, update the plant-specific views in MM02. Ensure the material is extended to the new plant and relevant valuation data is maintained.

SAP tracks equipment usage via

  • Equipment history (IH08): Shows installation, location changes, and maintenance history.
  • Maintenance orders and notifications: Linked to equipment and plant.
  • Asset history sheet (S_ALR_87011990): Shows asset movements and value changes.

To trace usage at the plant level, ensure Equipment is always updated with the correct plant and Maintenance orders are created under the correct plant and equipment.

entry.title: Re: Cross-company contribution margin
entry.content:
See that your S/4HANA system is activated for account-based CO-PA (also called Margin Analysis). It replaces costing-based CO-PA as the default for profitability reporting. It integrates tightly with the Universal Journal (table ACDOCA), making reconciliation with FI and CO much easier. You can still activate costing-based CO-PA if needed, but it‚Äôs no longer the preferred approach.

Set up intercompany billing between Company A and B. Ensure Company A posts COGS and intercompany revenue. Company B posts inventory receipt and customer revenue. Use transfer pricing if needed to reflect internal margins.

Use COPA derivation rules to pull Profit center from material master or sales order. Plant of production from delivery or production order. Ensure these characteristics are included in your operating concern.

entry.title: Re: IAM Apps tab missing in Maintain Business Roles app a...
entry.content:
Good day @beampakorn 

Thank you for your question.

Why do IAM tabs disappear?

This usually means that either the IAM business catalogs or their dependent UI components were not properly activate in your QAS tenant. Their is a dependency on presence of IAM in catalogs & IAM Service Activation in Tenant.

In summary, the Maintain Business Roles app is dynamically displayed based on the availability and activation of the IAM business catalogs and scope item 2XU (Identity and Access Management) in your tenant.

Please note, when you transport a role from your DEV to QAS:

  • If your IAM catalogs are not yet activated in QAS, or
  • If your Identity and Access Management scope is not active,

then the system hides the IAM Apps tab, even though other tabs e.g., Business Catalogs, Restriction, etc appear normally.

Below are steps you can take to solve that issue in the public cloud edition:

  1. In your QAS, open Manage Business Catalogs and activate all SAP_CORE_BC_IAM catalogs.
  2. In CBC, ensure the Identity and Access Management is active.
  3. Ensure you clear Fiori cache and reopen Maintain Business Roles.

Once you have fully activated IAM in QAS, the IAM Apps tab will appear, and you will require no extra authorisation or enhancement.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Identity and Access Management

Work with IAM Apps of the App Authorization Variant Type

Business Roles, Business Catalogs, App Authorization Variants, Restrictions

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: The Future of Planning in Excel: The SAP Analytics Cloud Add-in as a Strategic Frontend ‚Äì Part 2/3
entry.content:
Part 2/3: Data Validation

In the first part of this series, we introduced the SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) add-in for Microsoft Office and positioned it as the strategic successor to Analysis for Office. We covered its modern architecture, seamless integration, and how to build a basic interactive planning sheet.

Now it‚Äôs time to move beyond simple data display and entry. In this second instalment, we‚Äôll dive into one of the most powerful aspects of the add-in: how it works together with native Excel formulas. We‚Äôll show how to use those formulas to create a practical, robust, and essential tool for any planner: a self-service data-validation sheet.

Use case

In most planning processes, a small group of ‚Äúkey users‚Äù monitors and oversees progress. They remind contributors to enter data, catch mistakes early, and help maintain overall planning quality.

In later stages of a planning cycle, it becomes strategically important to know what changed compared to yesterday and why it changed. To streamline this, the SAP Analytics Cloud add-in can be combined with standard Excel techniques to build a lightweight validation hub.

Step 1: Create summary tables for the relevant dimensions

Create one or more SAC-connected tables that summarise your planning data by the dimensions you care about.
Example: in this post we use Country and Material, but in your scenario, it could be Cost Center, Product Group, Customer, etc.

Make sure each table is clearly labelled and, if helpful, filtered to the current planning year for quick scanning.

Step 2: Build a validation sheet with native Excel formulas

On a separate worksheet (‚ÄúValidation‚Äù or similar), use standard Excel functions to pull and compare values from the SAC-connected tables.

This gives you a single list of values drawn from your summary tables, ready for checks and comparisons.

Tips for the validation sheet

  • Lookup & aggregation: Use XLOOKUP, INDEX/MATCH, SUMIFS, or AGGREGATE to retrieve totals for each combination (or whichever grain you need).
  • Change tracking: Add a ‚ÄúYesterday‚Äù (or ‚ÄúBaseline‚Äù) column populated from a prior snapshot (copy-pasted values, a versioned table, or a dated export). Then compute Delta columns.
  • Quality checks: Use simple rules to flag issues like:
    • Missing values where entries are required.
    • Negative or unusually large values.
    • Unexpected zeros for active entities.
  • Conditional formatting: Highlight deltas above a threshold, blanks, or outliers so key users can see problems immediately.
  • Filters & slices: Add filters (e.g., by Region, Planner, Version) to narrow the validation view during review meetings.
  • Notes column: Include a free-text column so reviewers can record the reason for changes (price update, volume re-forecast, currency effect, etc.).

Why this works

  • Self-service: Planners and key users can validate data in Excel without leaving the SAC context.
  • Speed: Native formulas keep it fast and flexible; no macros required.
  • Governance: Clear flags and notes improve auditability and help explain variances.

What‚Äôs next (Part 3)

In the final part of this series, we‚Äôll show you how to transform your Excel sheet into a lightweight automation hub, enabling automatic data entry and streamlined updates to parameter values across your planning solution.

entry.title: Re: Transaction MD74 Fails to Clear VSF Scheduling Data f...
entry.content:
Some of the possible reasons why MD74 didn‚Äôt delete VSF Data are

  • MD74 only deletes PIRs from inactive planning versions. If the VSF data is in version 00 (active), MD74 won‚Äôt remove it. Try with MD62 to manually delete PIRs from active versions.
  • PIRs may be soft pegged to dependent requirements or planned orders. This prevents deletion via MD74. Check for linked elements using MD04 or MD05 for the material and plant.
  • Ensure the key date (21.10.2025) is correctly interpreted by the system. MD74 deletes PIRs up to and including the key date. Confirm that the schedule line 18-102025 falls within this range.

To fix this, perform the below steps

  • Run MD62 for material L003351135NCPAA in plant 5300. Select version 00. Manually delete PIRs for date 18-10-2025.
  • Check MD04 for pegged requirements. If linked to planned orders or reservations, delete those first.
  • Check Strategy Group in material master MRP3 view. Ensure strategy supports PIR deletion (e.g., 10, 40).
  • Use Transaction MD73, analyze PIRs by version and date. Confirm which entries are eligible for deletion.

entry.title: DIY JDBC Sender Adapter for SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
DIY JDBC Sender Adapter for SAP Integration Suite

Introduction

Are you migrating from SAP PO to Integration Suite and missing the JDBC Sender Adapter for various integration scenarios? If so, I have just the solution for you! In this article I will show you, how to simulate a JDBC Sender Adapter using a smart design approach. My method allows both scheduled and manual triggering (without redeploying your IFlow). I'll guide you step by step through my implementation to enable you to do the same on your use case.

Core Insight

You can simulate a JDBC Sender Adapter by configuring the Request/Reply step and incorporating your needed triggers.

My Step-by-Step Implementation

Entire Integration Process

Part 1: Polling and Decoupling 

  1. Scheduler & Manual Polling

    • I created two entry points for the integration flow:
      • A configurable scheduler for periodic database polls.
      • An HTTP endpoint for manual polling via Postman GET‚Äîperfect for testing or urgent triggers.
  2. Manual and Scheduled Fetch ProcessPolling the Sender DB
  • Used a local subprocess with a Request/Reply step to fetch data from the source database.
  • The fetched data is safely written to a DataStore or a JMS Queue (choose what suits your tenant/scenario) for decoupling and most importantly(at least for me): Retry handling.
SELECT * FROM ${property.JDBC_Schema}.${property.JDBC_Table};

JDBC Poll Process

Part 2: Mapping and Writing to Target DB

Write Data to Target

 

  1. Reading from DataStore/JMS Queue
    • In a second integration process, the data is read from the queue or store.
    • Exchange the sender adapter as needed.
  2. Message Mapping in a Local Subprocess
    • I placed mapping logic inside a local subprocess to isolate errors.
    • If mapping fails, it sets a custom status MappingFailed. 
    • Mapping errors cannot be retried, so the message escalates directly.
      local Mapping Process
  3. Insert into Target DB
    • After a successful mapping, data is inserted into the target database.

Error Handling

  • Errors are sent to a global error handling process, which checks the Nr of retries against the configured max and then yields an end event.
    • Automatic retries is triggered with an Error End.
    • Max retries reached, the message was sent to a Dead Letter Queue (DataStore) and escalates.
      Retry Handling Process
  • Mapping errors escalate instantly. They need to be resolved manually. 

Recommendations for Integration Developers

  • Decouple processes using DataStore or JMS Queue; which makes error handling and retries much easier.
  • Design your flow to be manually triggerable (e.g., via Postman or another IFlow) which comes in handy in an error case or for testing.

Personal Reflection

Honestly, I was surprised at how well this workaround performed, especially with error handling and decoupling. It‚Äôs not as plug-and-play as a native JDBC Sender Adapter in PO. I created a "template" IFlow from this concept, which I can copy everywhere I need. I already migrated multiple scenarios like that and it is almost as plug-and-play as in SAP PO. If you are interested in the template or have any question regarding this topic, contact me!

SAP Integration Suite

entry.title: Obtaining an OAuth Token from SAP XSUAA on SAP BTP Trial ‚Äì A Step-by-Step Guide
entry.content:
Introduction

This guide demonstrates how to obtain an OAuth access token from the SAP XSUAA (XS User Account and Authentication) service in a SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) trial environment using the client_credentials grant type.

The process covers the creation of the XSUAA service instance, generation of a service key, and retrieval of an access token using curl. This tutorial assumes familiarity with SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry CLI and basic authentication concepts.

1. Define the Security Descriptor

Create a file named xs-security.json with the following content:

{
    "xsappname": "xsuaa-demo",
    "tenant-mode": "dedicated",
    "scopes": [
        {
            "name": "$XSAPPNAME.scope",
            "description": "Default application scope"
        }
    ],
    "role-templates": [
        {
            "name": "Default",
            "description": "Default role",
            "scope-references": [
                "$XSAPPNAME.scope"
            ]
        }
    ]
}

This file defines the application name, scope, and role templates required by the XSUAA service.

2. Create the XSUAA Instance

Using the Cloud Foundry CLI, create the XSUAA service instance:

cf create-service xsuaa application xsuaa-demo -c xs-security.json

Verify that the service has been successfully created:

cf service xsuaa-demo

Ensure the status shows create succeeded before proceeding.

3. Create and Retrieve a Service Key

Next, create a service key to retrieve the credentials required for authentication.

cf create-service-key xsuaa-demo xsuaa-demo-key cf service-key xsuaa-demo xsuaa-demo-key

The output will contain details similar to the following (sensitive values are substituted, <CLIENT_SECRET>, etc):

{
    "credentials": {
        "clientid": "<CLIENT_ID>",
        "clientsecret": "<CLIENT_SECRET>",
        "url": "https://<YOUR_AUTH_DOMAIN>/oauth/token",
        "xsappname": "xsuaa-demo!tXXXXXX"
    }
}

The clientid, clientsecret, and url will be used in the next step to request an access token.

4. Request an Access Token

To obtain an access token, use the client_credentials flow.
Note: If your clientid contains special characters such as ‚Äú!‚Äù, ensure it is wrapped in single quotes to avoid shell expansion.

curl -X POST \
    -u '<CLIENT_ID>:<CLIENT_SECRET>' \
    -d 'grant_type=client_credentials&response_type=token' \
    'https://<YOUR_AUTH_DOMAIN>/oauth/token'

Upon success, the XSUAA service will return a JSON payload similar to the following:

{
    "access_token": "<ACCESS_TOKEN>",
    "token_type": "bearer",
    "expires_in": 43199,
    "scope": "uaa.resource"
}

This token can now be used to authenticate requests to other SAP services or applications secured by XSUAA.

5. Test the Token

To verify that the token is valid, include it in the Authorization header when calling a protected endpoint:

curl -H "Authorization: Bearer <ACCESS_TOKEN>" \ https://<YOUR_APP_DOMAIN>/hello

Expected response:

Hello authenticated user!

6. Common Issues

1. Special characters in client ID or secret
Use single quotes around credentials to prevent shell interpretation errors.

2. Region mismatch
Ensure the domain in your XSUAA credentials matches the region in which your BTP subaccount resides (for example, us10 or eu10).

3. Trial environment delays
In some cases, service provisioning in trial accounts may take longer than expected.

4. Security best practices
Do not expose your client credentials or tokens in source code or public repositories.

Conclusion

This guide outlines the complete process for generating and using an OAuth token from SAP‚Äôs XSUAA service in a BTP trial environment. Following these steps provides a reliable foundation for integrating authentication into SAP-based applications or services.

Keywords: SAP BTP, XSUAA, OAuth2, Cloud Foundry, Authentication, Security, Tutorial

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytics cloud : How Valur Driver Tree Inverse f...
entry.content:
@kiran_s611 

Inverse Formula works in the order its defined. The highest priority is the main the formula and then for inverse it takes the order in which you define them. So in your case the below formula is define for [001] Volume = Price * Quantity

 [002]*[003]|(INVERSE([002]:=[001]/[003]) or (INVERSE([003]:=[001]/[002])))

Volume will be calculated using price and Quantity and if Volume is adjusted then price will be calculated as its defined in that order. Also un booked items are treated as 0 so in this case if volume is un booked and you enter quantity price might not calculate.

Both Quantity and Price cannot be adjusted in proportion of a increase in volume. 10% increase in volume will not be same as increase of 10% price and 10% quantity.

 

Hope this helps !

Nikhil

Nikhil

entry.title: How to avoid double netting of stock between SAP IBP and S/4HANA MRP during planned order creation?
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

In our SAP IBP Supply Planning process, we are generating planned production orders at the plant level based on net demand (i.e., demand reduced available stock). These planned orders are then transferred to S/4HANA for execution, where MRP is also run.

However, since both IBP and S/4 MRP consider the same available stock, the stock is effectively netted twice ‚Äî once in IBP during planning, and again in S/4 during MRP run. This results in reduced or deleted planned orders after MRP execution.

What is the best practice or recommended system setup to avoid this double netting situation?
Should stock netting be handled only in IBP, or only in S/4, or is there a specific configuration (e.g., MRP type, firming, or planning strategy) to ensure that stock is not deducted twice when IBP planned orders are transferred to S/4HANA?

entry.title: CPI-Quicks #1: How to transform an IFlow Into an API Artifact
entry.content:
Here's a quick tip for anyone who wants to keep their Integration Suite "semantically clean": How to transform an IFlow into an API artifact.

The Short Version

When using a HTTP sender adapter, logically you should also use an API artifact, because the adapter exposes an endpoint like an API. But I don't always think about that, when I start out designing a process. In the past, I had to re-implement a whole new API artifact, copying and pasting all flow steps and messing up configurations on the way. Until I found out that you can turn an Integration Flow into a REST or SOAP API artifact by changing just one line in its manifest file. 

How-to (Step-by-Step)

  1. Spot the Difference

    • Under the hood, API Artifacts and Integration Flows are almost the same. The only real difference is the value of SAP-BundleType in the MANIFEST.MF file.
    • That tiny detail is what lets you make the switch.

  1. Download Your Integration Flow

    • Grab your IFlow artifact from SAP Integration Suite.

  2. Unzip and Look Inside

    • Open the zip file and go to /META-INF/MANIFEST.MF.

  3. Change the Manifest

    • Find the line that says:

      SAP-BundleType: IntegrationFlow

    • Change it to either:

      SAP-BundleType: SOAPAPIProvider

      or

      SAP-BundleType: RESTAPIProvider

      depending on what you need.

  4. Zip It Back Up

    • Save your changes, then re-zip the whole artifact folder.
      zip IFlow source

  5. Upload as an API Artifact

    • In SAP Integration Suite, start a new API Artifact, choose ‚ÄúUpload,‚Äù and pick your updated zip file.
    • Give it a name, hit ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù and ‚ÄúDeploy.‚Äù
      Create API Artifact

  6. Done!

    • You‚Äôve just turned your Integration Flow into a REST or SOAP API Artifact‚Äîwithout repeating all your work.

      two IFlows converted into two APIs

Caution!

  • Be Careful: Editing manifest files directly can be risky. Double-check everything before you deploy.
  • Always keep a copy of your IFlow at hand, so you are save when you mess something up.

Thank you for reading and may this trick save you some hours!

SAP Integration Suite API

entry.title: Re: Output message triggered even Output ignored (require...
entry.content:
Since 902 is a custom routine and added logic specific to the Business, it is not sure, how this can happen. However, please note, output type ZEOR might be reprocessed manually via VL71 or automatically via a background job. These jobs do not re-evaluate the routine, they simply process existing output records.

Check if ZEOR is set to trigger automatically in condition records (NACE ‚Üí V2 ‚Üí Output Types). If so, it may be added to the delivery regardless of the routine result, and then processed unless explicitly suppressed.

If ZEOR is linked to a specific partner function (e.g., SH or SP), and that partner is present, the output may trigger independently of the routine logic.

So go to VL03N ‚Üí Extras ‚Üí Output ‚Üí Header. Check if ZEOR was added manually or via default condition record.

Review SM37 for jobs running RSNAST00 or similar. These jobs process existing outputs and do not re-evaluate the routine.

Add a breakpoint in routine 902 and simulate delivery creation to confirm it‚Äôs being called and SY-SUBRC is set correctly.

entry.title: Re: ChaRM 4 system landscape not importing to Pre-Prod
entry.content:
I would like to add just that preliminary import is not something that happens in every Normal Change. You have to go through status "request preliminary import", because this way there is a preliminary import flag added to the Normal Change, and the status changes trigger the imports. Whereas, if you don't do the request preliminary import step, some of the same statuses are used by the classic Normal Change process (Imported in production, for example), but don't trigger imports at the status change.

Also, in the help page for preliminary import , it explicitly states that the status "tested for production import" lines up with the transport request being put in the production system import queue. My recommendation is that, if the names of statuses seem confusing, there is the possibility of customizing the names of statuses, import actions in each status, etc.

entry.title: Re: Fiori Launchpad for Sourcing and Procurement
entry.content:
Hi @JackN11 

In public cloud edition, the Supplier Down Payments process is delivered through the 18B scope item. You can enable it by:

  1. Go to your Central Business Configuration (CBC), --> then activate scope item 18B (Supplier Down Payments) under Finance --> Accounts Payable.
  2. Deploy the configuration so the related SSCUIs and business roles are available.
  3. Then, in SSCUI (Define Terms of Payment), create or edit a payment term and set the Down Payment Indicator to X.
  4. Assign this term to your PO or supplier.

After activation, you can use:

  • Display Supplier Down Payment Requests
  • Manage Supplier Line Items
  • Monitor Purchase Order Items
  • Display Supplier Balances

to track and manage down payments across procurement and finance.

If 18B doesn‚Äôt appear in CBC, ensure to verify your country localisation and scope phase, or open an incident.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Manage Supplier Down Payment Requests

Approval Workflows for Supplier Down Payment Requests

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: About scope items for material closing period(MMPV)
entry.content:
Hello @ki2003 ,

As @FernandaKlauck explained in his post,

The Material Closing Period (MMPV) function was never moved to 3F0; it remains accessible via the Close Periods (F2540) app under Master Data ‚Äì Administration. The 3F0 scope covers event-based costing, with material period close continuing separately.

This page describes how users open or close posting periods for logistics areas like Materials Management. This functionality, formerly managed through transaction MMPV, is now integrated into the SAP Fiori app instead of the 3F0 (Event-Based Costing) scope. SAP Help-General Ledger Accounting-Opening and Closing Posting Periods

BEI ‚Üí 3F0: BEI Period-End Closing ‚Äì Plant deprecated as of 2408, decommissioned in 2602; costing moves to 3F0 Event-Based Production Cost Posting KBA -3599914 - About the transition from the scope item BEI to the scope item 3F0

Why 3F0 test scripts don‚Äôt show MMPV: 3F0 handles event-based production cost posting. The material posting period closes the classic ‚ÄúMMPV‚Äù function, which is separate from logistics control. SAP Help Portal-Product Accounting-Event-Based (3F0) versus Period-Based (BEI) in Production Costs of Manufacturing Orders

MMPV's current location: Use the Close Periods feature in S/4HANA Cloud (Fiori) via Master Data ‚Üí Administration to open or close MM posting periods. SAP‚Äôs help documentation and SAP blog provide the title and navigation path.  SAP Help Portal-Create New Open MM Posting Period - MDS (BNZ)-Closing MM Period and Opening New Posting Period

Authorisations to run Close Periods: If users cannot see or run it, check authorisations. KBA 2748224 documents the Close Periods app error ‚ÄúNo authorization to carry out period closing‚Äù and mentions the relevant business roles/catalogues.

In brief

  • MMPV wasn‚Äôt moved into 3F0, so you won‚Äôt find it in 3F0 test scripts.
  • Continue to close MM periods via Close Periods (Fiori) under Master Data ‚Üí Administration; ensure proper authorisation as per KBA 2748224.
  • The BEI ‚Üí 3F0 change affects production costing, not the existence of the Close Periods activity.

Let me know if you need further support

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Mass maintenance catalog for business partners
entry.content:
Hi @JackN11 

Here is a step-by-step process you can follow:

Either you use the Mass Change of Business Partners app or use the Maintain Business Roles app (this is what i use for the description here) which you can find in your IAM tile.

Go to:

  1. Maintain Business Roles app, search for the role SAP_BR_BUPA_MASTER_SPECIALIST or SAP_BR_BUPA_MASTER_DATA_SUPERVISOR
  2. Copy the role to your Z-role or you can edit your existing custom role.
  3. In the role, assign Assigned Business Catalogs and add: SAP_CMD_BC_BUSINESS_PARTNER_PC  (this is the successor to the old mass-maintenance catalog)
  4. Save the role.

Still in IAM, open Maintain Business Users, find your user, then edit, assign business roles, add the Z-role mentioned earlier and save. Then log out and in again.

Here is how you can identify successor catalogs next time you may require it

Open Business Cataltogs or Maintain Business Roles.

Search the app Mass change of Business Partners √† open the app info pane √† it shows the current catalog that delivers it (here: SAP_CMD_BC_BUSINES_ PARTNER_MAINT_PC)

If your app still doesn‚Äôt appear, ensure your role includes mentioned earlier and that you have re-logged in. If you space doesn‚Äôt show the tile; use the search function to add it to My Home. Keep your catalogs in custom roles (Z) so future upgrades don‚Äôt overwrite your changes.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: OnSave Business Rule for dependents
entry.content:
Hi All,

I would like to ask you the question regarding the onSave business rule used for the validation of the date of birth for the dependents. My client asked to enable the validation that if the DOB of a new joiner in onboarding is on or before the DOB of a dependent set to father or mother, then the error message should display.

I achieved this with the simple business rule assigned to personRelationshipInfo as onSave. The rule works when the condition is met, it even works when the data is corrected (i.e. DOB is corrected, relationship type is changed from father/mother to something else) - and this is where the issue occurs. With that the onboarding process will get stacked. I tried to modify the rule by following the suggestion from this KBA, but I am unable to use previous value since Employee Information as the base object. Using Employee Information Model causes that the rule does not work (the error does not trigger); same happens when I use dependents model.

What I tried as the alternative is to create the onChange rule which would remove the DOB of a dependent. I managed to trigger this rule, but only when the relationship type is changed (which is not ideal, because a new joiner will not be changing the relationship type in this case, rather the DOB). The problem is the rule removes only the current value, and not the old value, hence the error still displays when you reach the end of the data collection step.

Alternatively I changed the severity of the message to warning, but the warning will still display even after correcting the data, which will not block the onb process, but will be confusing for the end user.

Does anyone knows how to workaround this? I spent way too much time on this and could not find the solution.

I attached the screen shots of both rules for your reference.

Regards,

Piotr Retecki

entry.title: Re: remove the payment advice number from Feban
entry.content:
Hi Misha,
Refer to your issue to remove or restrict the payment advice number in SAP FEBAN, you need to adjust the Electronic Bank Statement (EBS) configuration and possibly suppress payment advice creation during post-processing. You can follow the approach to address this issue. Please fine the steps to remove or restrict Payment Advice Number in FEBAN

1. Review Posting Rules in FF_5 Configuration.
Go to transaction OT83 or OT84 depending on your system version.
Check the posting rules assigned to your bank transaction codes.
Ensure that the rule does not trigger payment advice creation unless necessary.

2. Suppress Payment Advice Creation
In the EBS configuration, set the posting area 2 to avoid generating payment advice notes.
You can also modify the interpretation algorithm to prevent linking payment advice numbers to line items.

3. Use User Exit or BADI
Implement a user exit or BADI (e.g., FEB_BADI) to control or suppress the payment advice number dynamically during FEBAN processing.
This allows you to apply custom logic based on document type, amount, or other criteria.

4. Manual Removal in FEBAN
If the advice number is already present, you can manually clear or adjust the entry in FEBAN:
Open FEBAN.
Select the line item.
Use the ‚ÄúChange‚Äù option to remove the payment advice reference.
Reprocess the item to ensure proper posting.

5. Prevent Double Posting
Ensure that the payment advice number is not reused across multiple transactions.
You may need to adjust your clearing settings or duplicate check logic in SAP to prevent this.

Hope the above suggestion helped you.

entry.title: Re: Created Custom Business Object in SAP Public Cloud In...
entry.content:
Hi @shivakumar_p 

The fact you don‚Äôt have Form Template Usage option your Custom CDS View, this hints that it was not built on a released data source and service generation was probably not enabled.

Since your CDS is based on a Custom Business Object, make sure you have:

  • Opened your CBO, activated Service Generation and UI Generation.
  • Published the CBO
  • Created a CDS View using the CBO as primary data source.
  • You will then see the checkbox Form Template Usage; ensure you select and publish it.
  • The CDS now appears in Maintain Form Templates as a valid data source.

Without you enabling service, the system cannot expose the CBO to the form framework. This explains why you can‚Äôt see the Form Template option.

After you have enabled it, you can link the form to your custom button through custom logic that calls the form service API to download or print the report.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Issue with CJ88: "Either the sender is already settle...
entry.content:
Dear Mohideen Sait,
Yes, you can implement a short delay in your macro is the most reliable solution to ensure CJ88 executes successfully after FB01 posting.

I have few more suggestions for you. Please find them below.

1. Add a Delay in the Macro
Introduce a wait time of 5‚Äì10 seconds between FB01 and CJ88 execution.
This allows SAP to complete internal updates and ensures the settlement finds the posted values.
You can use a WAIT statement or a timer function depending on your macro environment.

2. Use Commit Work and Wait (if scripting in ABAP)
If your macro interacts with ABAP or BAPI calls, ensure COMMIT WORK AND WAIT is used after FB01.
This forces SAP to complete all updates before proceeding.

3. Check for Posting Confirmation
If feasible, add a check to confirm that the document posted in FB01 is visible in the relevant tables (e.g., COEP or COBK) before triggering CJ88.

4. Batch Job Alternative
If automation is critical, consider scheduling CJ88 as a background job with a slight delay after FB01 posting.


Hope above suggestions work for you.

entry.title: Unlock the Power of Analytics with the New SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 Customer Playbook
entry.content:
Are you ready to take your sales and service operations to the next level? The brand-new SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 Customer Playbook ‚Äì Analytics is here to help you unlock the full potential of embedded analytics in your SAP environment. 

 

Why Analytics Matter More Than Ever 

In today‚Äôs fast-paced business world, having real-time insights is not just a luxury‚Äîit‚Äôs a necessity. The playbook shows how Embedded SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) empowers both end users and key users to build, consume, and act on analytical content directly within SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2. With role-based dashboards, KPIs, and real-time reporting, you can make smarter decisions, faster. 

 

What‚Äôs Inside the Playbook? 

  • Clear Value Propositions: Learn how analytics save time, improve efficiency, and keep your teams on target. No more manual data crunching‚Äîget critical information at your fingertips. 
  • Step-by-Step Adoption Guidance: Identify opportunities for analytics adoption across sales managers, reps, service managers, and administrators. The playbook helps you assess your current visibility and highlights where analytics can drive the most impact. 
  • Lead-to-Cash Journey Mapping: See how analytics support every stage of the customer journey‚Äîfrom lead qualification and opportunity conversion to order delivery and post-sale follow-up. 
  • Business KPIs That Matter: Discover the key metrics that drive sales and service success, including pipeline management, lead conversion rates, SLA compliance, and agent performance. 
  • Best Practices and Real Results: Explore real-world examples and best practices that have delivered measurable business outcomes, such as faster opportunity identification, improved data quality, and optimized service team performance. 
  • Getting Started Made Easy: The playbook provides practical setup instructions for provisioning SAC, configuring single sign-on, managing user replication, and designing analytical stories tailored to your business roles. 

 

See Analytics in Action 

The playbook is packed with visuals and examples, including: 

  • Home screen KPI dashboards for sales reps 
  • Lead funnel and pipeline insights 
  • Forecast trackers and pipeline flow diagrams 
  • Service case overviews and escalation metrics 
  • Agent performance dashboards and SLA compliance tracking 

Resources at Your Fingertips 

Ready to dive deeper? The playbook links to solution guides, webcasts, blogs, and video tutorials to help you get started and maximize your analytics investment. 

Don‚Äôt miss out on the opportunity to transform your sales and service operations. Download the new SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 Customer Playbook ‚Äì Analytics today and empower your teams with the insights they need to succeed!

entry.title: SIT Berlin Website Live Now With All Session Recordings
entry.content:
SAP Inside Tracks are still are for me personally still one of the best things that came out of the SAP community, bringing so many people together all around the world. I did my part with the organization of SAP Inside Track Berlin during the years from 2017 to 2019, one of my personal highlights being part of SAP and its amazing community.

And now finally after all these years, SAP Inside Track Berlin has its very own website: https://sitberlin.net

For everyone who has been part of the Berlin SIT community (and for those who‚Äôve always wanted to join), this is the new home where all the great content from our events comes together. Every single session from SIT Berlin has been recorded and is available on the website. Whether you missed a talk or just want to revisit one of your favorites, you can find it there. Much of the content is evergreen like the 101 of Machine Learning aka AI, Design Thinking practices, and other topics that are still worth watching today (some things change very slowly in the SAP ecosystem).

I also made available all the photos we took during the events, hopefully giving you some better insight of the event. And for the people that attended any of the events, they hopefully bring back good memories üôÇ

Of course the site has been vibe-coded and it was a lot of fun and not much effort to create something that truly reflects the spirit of our local community: open, creative, and full of good energy. The website code is available on Github, just in case anybody is eager to have a look. also feel free to open to provide feedback vie Github issues.

Visit OpenSIT for more SIT content

If you want to explore even more SAP Inside Track recordings from around the world, head over to OpenSIT where I aggregated the recorded sessions from many other SAP Inside Tracks.

See you at SAP TechEd Berlin

And while I'm not with SAP anymore, I‚Äôm already looking forward to seeing many of my friends (and meeting some new ones) at SAP TechEd in November in Berlin. Until then, have fun exploring the new site and revisiting all the great moments from SIT Berlin.

entry.title: Find Your Path to SAP Cloud ERP: Introducing the Transformation Approach Finder
entry.content:
As organizations prepare to transition from SAP ECC to SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP, one question consistently arises: Which transformation path is right for us? At SAP, we understand that every customer journey is unique. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre excited to introduce a new feature in SAP Business Transformation Center‚Äîthe ‚ÄúFind Transformation Approach‚Äù app, now available in SAP Cloud ALM.

This innovative guidance tool helps customers identify the most suitable transition path based on their current landscape, business goals, and transformation readiness.

Three Proven Paths to SAP Cloud ERP

The transformation journey from ECC to SAP Cloud ERP typically follows one of three approaches. Let‚Äôs explore each, along with the tools SAP provides to support them:

1. System Conversion

Best for: Customers who want to retain their existing ECC system structure and migrate it to SAP S/4HANA.

  • Tool: Software Update Manager (SUM)
  • Highlights: Technical conversion of an existing system, preserving historical data and configuration.

 

 

2. Selective Data Transition

Best for: Customers who want to move only relevant data including history selectively into an empty SAP S/4HANA shell system.

  • Tool: SAP Business Transformation Center
  • Scenario: Lean Selective Data Transition
  • Highlights: Combines the benefits of system conversion and new implementation. Enables process redesign and selective data migration.

 

3. New Implementation

Best for: Customers aiming for a fresh start with SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP.

  • Tool: SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit
  • Highlights: Clean slate approach with data migration from legacy systems into a new cloud environment.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

How the ‚ÄúFind Transformation Approach‚Äù App Works

The ‚ÄúFind Transformation Approach‚Äù app in SAP Business Transformation Center is designed to guide customers through the decision-making process for transitioning from SAP ECC to SAP Cloud ERP. It does not replace expert-led discovery workshops but complements them by providing a structured, data-driven starting point.

Step 1: System Analysis

Before any assessments are made, the app leverages two key SAP tools to analyze the source system:

  • Maintenance Readiness Check: This check collects technical information from the source SAP ECC system:
    üìëSAP Note 3620764: Execute Maintenance Readiness Check (MRC) on local system and store result as file

  • SAP Readiness Check for Usage and Data Profiling: This provides application-level insights into business process usage, data volumes, and complexity.
    üìëSAP Note 3275056 : SAP Readiness Check for SAP ERP Usage and Data Profiling

Those can be uploaded using the app "Manage Analysis Files" also part of SAP Business Transformation Center.

Step 2: System Insights

The Initial System Insights screen provides a high-level overview of the source SAP ECC system, based on data collected through the Maintenance Readiness Check and SAP Readiness Check for Usage and Data Profiling.

These insights include:

  • Technical System Information
    Derived from the Maintenance Readiness Check, this includes:

    • System version and patch level
    • Installed components and add-ons
    • Custom code footprint
    • Database and operating system details

  • Application Usage and Data Profiling
    Provided by the SAP Readiness Check, this includes:

    • Most-used transactions and modules
    • Data volumes by application area
    • Archiving status and data aging
    • Business process complexity

These insights form the foundation for the preliminary transformation assessment, helping customers understand their system‚Äôs readiness and complexity before diving into the detailed questionnaire.

 

Step 3: Preliminary Assessment

Based on the collected system data, the app generates an initial preliminary assessment suggesting the most suitable transformation approach‚ÄîSystem Conversion, Selective Data Transition, or New Implementation.

Customers can review and verify the preliminary assessment and proceed to a detailed questionnaire. This step allows refinement based on business priorities, transformation goals, and organizational readiness.

 

Step 4: Verification and Refinement

After reviewing the preliminary assessment, users are invited to complete a structured questionnaire to refine the transformation approach recommendation. This step is crucial for tailoring the guidance to the organization‚Äôs specific transformation context.

The questionnaire covers several dimensions:

  • Business Priorities

    • Are you aiming for process standardization or innovation?
    • Do you want to retain historical data or start fresh?
    • Is cloud adoption a strategic goal?

  • Transformation Drivers

    • Regulatory or compliance requirements
    • End-of-maintenance timelines
    • Performance or scalability needs

  • IT Landscape Considerations

    • Number of ECC systems and their interdependencies
    • Custom developments and enhancements
    • Integration with non-SAP systems

  • Organizational Readiness

    • Availability of internal resources
    • Experience with previous transformation projects
    • Appetite for change and innovation

Each response helps refine the initial system-based assessment, ensuring that the final recommendation reflects both technical realities and strategic ambitions.

 

Step 5: Final Output

Once the questionnaire is completed, the app presents the best-fit transformation scenario, along with links to relevant tools, documentation, and next steps to support execution.

 

Step 6: Scenario Selection 

Independent from the assessment result, the user can choose a transformation scenario, in this case even though system conversion has the highest scoring, user has chosen the selective data transition scenario:

 

Step 7: Transformation Project Creation 

Once you've identified the best-fit transformation scenario using the Find Transformation Approach app, the next step is to put your plan into motion‚Äîand SAP makes that seamless.

Thanks to full integration with the transformation project capabilities in SAP Business Transformation Center, users can immediately create a transformation project tailored to the selected scenario. This ensures continuity between planning and execution, with no need to switch tools or re-enter data.

You can launch the Manage Transformation Project app directly from within the Find Transformation Approach app, or access it anytime via the Transformation tab in SAP Cloud ALM.

Whether you're pursuing a System Conversion, Selective Data Transition, or New Implementation, your transformation project becomes the central hub for managing the journey from ECC to SAP Cloud ERP.

Find out more details about the "Manage Transformation Project" capabilities in the respective blog post.

Important Note

The Find Transformation Approach app is a guidance tool, not a prescriptive engine. It supports informed decision-making but does not replace expert-led discovery workshops or transformation planning sessions. It is best used in addition to these engagements to accelerate alignment and readiness.

Why SAP Business Transformation Center?

SAP Business Transformation Center is more than a migration tool‚Äîit‚Äôs a strategic enabler. It helps customers:

  • Visualize their current ECC landscape
  • Plan transformation scenarios
  • Execute lean selective data transitions
  • Align IT and business stakeholders

With the new guidance feature, customers can confidently navigate their journey to SAP Cloud ERP.

Get Started Today

Explore the Find Transformation Approach app in SAP Business Transformation Center powered by SAP Cloud ALM and take the first step toward a smarter, faster, and more tailored ERP transformation.

Learn more on SAP Help Portal here

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud 2508 / Missing standard value in a c...
entry.content:
Hello @LukasKuhn 

Yes, this is possible. The default setting for Calculate Tax is determined by the business catalogue SAP_MM_BC_INV_PROCESS_PC (Accounts Payable ‚Äì Invoice Processing).

Add this catalogue or any standard role that contains it,such as SAP_BR_AP_ACCOUNTANT or SAP_BR_AP_ACCOUNTANT_PROCUREMT) to the user‚Äôs role, then log off/on.
After that, the Calculate Tax field will appear in Settings ‚Üí Default Values.

Let me know if it works

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Streamline Data Migration from SAP ECC to SAP S/4HANA: Selective Data Transition with Time-Slice
entry.content:
Hello @Necronomicon 

There are no restrictions on usage of SAP BTC related to the database size of the source system. Source system size will impact the runtime of the migration. But this also heavily depends on the system resources and source database performance. In order to provide a recommendation, all these parameters have to be checked and validated against the expected downtime window of the customer. We see projects where a proper DB parameterization which is then setup temporarily for the data migration load only leads to significant runtime increases.  We would recommend to explore the available options to reduce the target system size by applying org and/or time slice patterns. For a running customer project, we have a reduction from 2.6TB to approx. 600GB on the target side with org and time slice applied. The customer as well runs on Oracle on the source side.

There is no SAP note that specifies the concrete system configuration. You can refer to the section "Tuning the Data Transfer" in the Setup and Administration Guide. Based on feedback received we are currently revisiting the documentation and extending the guidance also based on source db. 

If you have a concrete customer project, running a PoC would also be a good option to verify the approach and check the runtime/duration. Once a tenant is available and if there should be any issues occur, you can also contact "us" the product team via a ticket as well. 

 

Thanks,

Matthias

SAP„ÅåÊé®ÈÄ≤„Åô„Çã„Äå„Éì„Ç∏„Éç„ÇπAI„ÄçÊà¶Áï•„ÅØ„ÄÅ„Ç¢„Éó„É™„Ç±„Éº„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„Éª„Éá„Éº„ÇøÂü∫Áõ§„ÉªAI„ÅÆ‰∏âÂ±§ÊßãÈÄ†„ÅßÊßãÊàê„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ„Åì„Çå„Çâ„ÅÆÂ±§„ÅåÁ∑äÂØÜ„Å´ÈÄ£Êê∫„Åô„Çã„Åì„Å®„Åß„ÄÅAI„ÅØÂÆüÈöõ„ÅÆ„Éì„Ç∏„Éç„Çπ„Ç≥„É≥„ÉÜ„Ç≠„Çπ„Éà„ÇíÁêÜËß£„Åó„ÄÅËá™ÂæãÁöÑ„Å´Ê•≠Âãô„ÇíÈÅÇË°å„Åß„Åç„Çã„Çà„ÅÜ„Å´„Å™„Çä„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ „Åæ„Åö„ÄÅSAP„ÅÆÂêÑÁ®Æ„Ç¢„Éó„É™„Ç±„Éº„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„ÅßÁô∫Áîü„Åô„Çã„Éì„Ç∏„Éç„Çπ„Éá„Éº„Çø„Çí„ÄÅSAP Business Data CloudÔºàBDCÔºâ„Åå‰∏ÄÂÖÉÁöÑ„Å´ÁÆ°ÁêÜ„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇBDC„ÅØ„ÄÅ„Ç¢„Éó„É™„Ç±„Éº„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„ÅßÁîüÊàê„Åï„Çå„ÇãËÜ®Â§ß„Å™„Éá„Éº„Çø„ÇíÊï¥ÂÇô„ÉªÁµ±Âêà„Åó„ÄÅAI„Ç®„Éº„Ç∏„Çß„É≥„Éà„ÅåÈ´òÁ≤æÂ∫¶„Å´Âãï‰Ωú„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆ‰ø°È†ºÊÄß„ÅÆÈ´ò„ÅÑÂü∫Áõ§„ÇíÊèê‰æõ„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ „Åô„Å™„Çè„Å°„ÄÅ„Ç¢„Éó„É™„Ç±„Éº„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„Å®BDC„ÅåÈÄ£Êê∫„Åô„Çã„Åì„Å®„Å´„Çà„Å£„Å¶Âàù„ÇÅ„Å¶„ÄÅAI„Ç®„Éº„Ç∏„Çß„É≥„Éà„ÅØ‚ÄúÂãï„Åè‚Äù„Åì„Å®„Åå„Åß„Åç„Çã„ÅÆ„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ„Åì„Çå„ÅåSAP„ÅÆ„Äå„Éì„Ç∏„Éç„ÇπAI„ÄçÊà¶Áï•„ÅÆÊ†πÂππ„Çí„Å™„ÅôËÄÉ„ÅàÊñπ„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ

entry.title: Prepare for 2602: Service Key and Service Binding Requests will change to asynchronous processing
entry.content:
Service Key and Service Binding Requests will change to asynchronous processing

Starting with release 2602, the service broker for the SAP BTP ABAP Environment will switch to asynchronous processing for service binding and service key creation requests. This change will impact client applications using interfaces like the CF CLI and CAPI.

Users of these tools/APIs need to modify their programs or scripts to prepare for this change!

Affected Interfaces

  • Cloud Foundry Command Line Interface (CF CLI)
  • Cloud Foundry Application Programming Interface (CAPI)

Read this document, if you use these calls

  • cf create-service-key
  • cf delete-service-key
  • cf bind-service
  • cf unbind-service
  • /v3/service_credential_bindings/<service binding guid> Endpoint (CF Service Credential Binding API)

Background Information

The SAP BTP ABAP Environment service broker implements the Open Service Broker API. All service offerings of this service allow to create and delete service bindings or service keys for existing SAP BTP ABAP Environment service instances. The service bindings / keys currently supported are:

  • Service Keys of the type oAuth for authentication on the ABAP System (e.g. when using the ABAP development tools)
  • Service Keys of the type basic auth for creating Communication Arrangements 
  • Service Bindings for the Integration with the Approuter

If the service broker receives a request to create (or delete) a service key or binding, it can fulfill this request synchronously or asynchronously. The Open Service Broker API allows the service broker to define the default behavior.

Up to now, these requests were processed synchronously per default.

Over time, it turned out that there are a number of situations where tasks couldn't finish within the synchronous processing timeout. Therefore we decided to change the future default to asynchronous.

Changing the default means, that client implementations need to be adapted before Release 2602: Make sure that you at least use version 8 of the cf cli or version 3 of the CF API to support asynchronous responses and that your implementation retrieves the error information as described below in detail.

Behavior up to Release 2602

Service binding create or delete requests are been processed synchronously.

  • If the call returns successfully, it means the operation was performed successfully.
  • If the call returns a failure, the error contains detailed information about what happened.

Behavior starting from Release 2602

Service binding create or delete requests are been processed asynchronously.

  • If the call returns successfully, it means the request has been successfully planned for execution in background.
  • If the call returns a failure, it means that the request could not be planned for execution.

General adaptation pattern

Make sure your code can work with the asynchronous execution of service binding create/delete operations.

Functionality that can help:

  • You can use the "wait" functionality to instruct the call to block until the the operation has been finished. (only cf cli).
  • You can read the state of the service binding for information about the processing progress and error details.

All our affected services have set the "bindings_retrievable" attribute to "true", which allows the retrieval of the state information.

Do not rely on return values and error messages of the request call. Instead query the state information either in a loop, or after the request call with "wait".

Specific adaptation recommendations per Interface

This chapter outlines only the relevant parts. Necessary, but unaffected parts (request handling, authorization handling etc.) have been left out.

Implementation recommendation (Cloud Foundry CLI)

For a detailed documentation of the Cloud Foundry CLI, see https://cli.cloudfoundry.org/en-US/v8/

Prerequisite: You should use cf cli version >= 8 (https://docs.cloudfoundry.org/cf-cli/v8.html ), which provides the "--wait" option to service binding operations.

Note: cf cli version >= 8 also results in the automatically inclusion of the query parameter "accepts_incomplete=true" in modifying requests to the service broker.

Use the "--wait" option in any of your modifying operations.

For example:

cf create-service-key <<service instance name>> <<service binding name>> -c <<parameters json object>> --wait
cf delete-service-key <<service instance name>> <<service binding name>> --wait

If you need the detailed error information in case of FAILED operations, do not rely on the cli return value.

Determine the service binding guid:

cf service-key <<service instance name>> <<service binding name>> --guid


Use the service binding guid to read the service binding details:

cf curl /v3/service_credential_bindings/<<service binding guid>>

The result data (in json format) should contain the property "last_operation" with a value being another object in json format

  • in case of a FAILED response on the service binding request
    • the property "state" of the object "last_operation" should be "failed"
    • the property "description" of the object "last_operation" should always contain a more detailed error message raised by the service broker.
  • in case of a OK response the service binding creation request
    • the property "state" of the object "last_operation" should be "succeeded"
    • evaluate the detailed data of the service binding for more information

Consequences for not following the recommendation (Cloud Foundry CLI)

  • Wrong assumption on "OK":
    The CLI call will immediately return "OK". However, this will no longer mean the request has been processed. It now means the request has been accepted and will be processed (in background). From there on, your client implementation may continue with the false assumption of success. The request is not yet finished and can still fail.
  • Wrong assumption on "FAILED":
    The response of the cli may not contain a detailed error message. It will return information about the process scheduler, but not the process itself.

Note: The "--wait" parameter can make the request call block until the process is finished, but it does not change the meaning of the "OK" or "FAILED" error messages.

Implementation recommendation (Cloud Foundry API)

For a detailed documentation of the CAPI, please see https://v3-apidocs.cloudfoundry.org/version/3.194.0/index.html#service-credential-binding

The request examples used in this chapter are based on curl syntax and they do not contain all necessary parameters/options for a successful https request (the examples also only refer to service bindings of binding type "key" and parameter type "basic").

Prerequisite: You should use a CAPI version >= 3.

Note: CAPI version >= 3 also leads to the automatic inclusion of the query parameter "accepts_incomplete=true" in modifying requests to the service broker.

If you create / delete service bindings with requests like these:

curl <<server part of url>>/v3/service_credential_bindings -X POST -H "Content-type: application/json" -d '{"type":"key","name":"<<service binding name>>","relationships":{"service_instance":{"data":{"guid":"<<service instance guid>>"}}},"parameters":{"type
":"basic","scenario_id":"<<specific scenario id>>"}}'
curl <<server part of url>>/v3/service_credential_bindings/<<service binding guid>> -X DELETE -H "Content-type: application/json"

The server will respond with:

  • HTTP Status Code 202 (Accepted)
    which means the service binding change request has been successfully created
  • a "Location" header which contains a url (including the id) to read data from the scheduled request operation from the service broker
  • In the error case: a response object (in json format) which contains the property "errors" which may contain multiple error messages

In order to correctly read the status of your request, evaluate the job data:

  • Determine the job guid by evaluating the url contained in the "Location" header or use the url directly
  • Use the job guid to recursively read the job data until you find a final state (include a meaningful waiting time)
    Example Request:
cf curl /v3/jobs/<<job guid>> -H "Content-type: application/json"‚Äã


Then evaluate the property "state" in the object of the json format response:

  • in case the property "state" has the value "PROCESSING" or "POLLING"
    • continue the polling with another read of the job data
  • in case the property "state" has the value "COMPLETE"
    • stop the polling and continue by reading the data for the service binding, if wanted
  • in case the property "state" has the value "FAILED"
    • Do not rely on the objects in the property "errors" in the response object. These won't contain the full error information about the request after 2602.

We recommend to handle the "FAILED" state in the following way:
Read the data for the service binding to ensure a detailed error message for the creation (or deletion).

  • Determine the service binding guid from the job data by evaluating the url contained in the property "service_credential_binding" or use the url directly
  • Use the service binding guid to read the service binding details
    Example request:
curl /v3/service_credential_bindings/<<service binding guid>> -H "Content-type: application/json"‚Äã
  • the response data (in json format) should contain the property "last_operation" with a value being another object in json format
    • the property "state" of the object "last_operation" should be "failed"
    • the property "description" of the object "last_operation" should always contain a more detailed error message raised by the service broker.

In case of non FAILED states, the response contains:

  • the property "state" of the object "last_operation" should be "succeeded"
  • evaluate the detailed data of the service binding, if wanted

Consequences for not following the recommendation (Cloud Foundry API)

In modifying requests (POST or DELETE), the server responds with an ‚ÄúOK‚Äù (HTTP status code 202 - Accepted) when the respective custom resource (AbapServiceBinding) could be created (or deletion triggered) in the underlying kubernetes cluster. This does not reflect the true state (succeeded, failed, processing) of the service binding. If you do not follow our recommendation to implement a polling mechanism, your implementation would assume, the service binding was successful, when it actually still in progress, or even failed.

We hope this blog post explains the change well and gives enough examples for you to adapt your code.
